I think I've seen Pimm's Cups before, but never had the pleasure of trying one until @kegel_robbe made me one last night. All you need is @pimmsgb and ginger ale and apparently, you're good to go! (Oh, and the fruit, of course!) I was surprised at first, expecting something sweet, but it really has a much lighter and more savory profile that is nice for relaxing in the sun.

So a big part of Danish culture revolves around these herbal liquors called "snaps." Scandinavian tradition has people sitting around a table, during the holidays, sharing a meal, and enjoying various types of snaps.

I've been waiting for a Dane to introduce me to these unique libations, but that doesn't appear to be happening, so I'm just going to start playing Russian roulette with bottles that I find at the grocery store and posting a description.

First up: Porse from @aalborg_akvavit 
Luckily, my first pick was a good one!! It's not the easiest sipping drink (40% ABV), but the spice and flavor help mellow the mouth feel. Woody bouquet. I get the feeling that snaps rely more on the flavors to carry them than utilizing sugar like other herbal liquors do. It's light, but deep. I get hints of cinnamon, rosemary, and cherry. I also taste something I can't quite name, but that might be bog myrtle (I'm only guessing that because it's written on the back of the bottle. ...I have no idea what "bog myrtle" tastes like!) I've tried this both room temperature and ice cold. The latter is the suggested method by Danes, but I actually prefer the former, I think. Chilling the beverage cuts out depth that you get at room temperature.

Overall, I'm quite pleased, and can't wait to try another!

My snaps exploration continues! This "random bottle of snaps" came from @opandersonaquavit and is much closer to what I was expecting from the stories people told me. It tastes like biting into a pumpernickel bagel and made me a little homesick. Again, I tried it at various temperatures and found it best mildly chilled. Too cold, and it loses depth; too warm and it burns a bit too much.

Other than caraway, I really don't get anything else which I found disappointing (who knows, maybe that's what they were aiming for). Coming off the Porse with its unique blend of flavors, I was expecting more than just caraway. It's not bad, just not as exciting.

I've been away from the game for a while, but I'm going to try to change that. And what better day to celebrate my return than Repeal Day?! On this day, in 1933, the United States government repealed the prohibition of alcohol. I chose a proper prohibition-era drink to honor this occasion: The Sidecar

2pt cognac
1pt @cointreau 
1pt lemon juice
1pt simple syrup

Add ingredients over ice. Mix. Rinse a coupe glass with orange bitters. Strain cocktail into glass. Garnish with an orange twist.

First black pepper cocktail! I wanted to make black pepper infused whiskey but I kinda overdid it. It turns out 6 oz of whiskey to 1 tablespoon of black pepper corns is NOT the right ratio. That burned in a lot of ways. ...I could cut it though and it became drinkable. Here's a "Peppered Whiskey Sour"

1.0 oz black pepper infused whiskey
2.0 oz rye whiskey
0.5 oz lemon juice
0.5 oz lime juice
1.0 oz simple syrup
3 dashes of black pepper and cardamom bitters
1 egg white

Add ingredients, except for egg white, to a shaker with ice. Shake. Strain. Remove ice. Add egg white. Add mix back in. Shake HARD. Pour into rocks glass. Garnish with a grind of black pepper and a few drops of bitters.

Happy Cinco de Mayo!! As I mentioned, a couple of us are doing a challenge to celebrate. We had to make a margarita that involves an exotic or tropical fruit. For my creation, I used Cucumis metuliferus, or kiwano. Also known as "horned melon" (it's also sometimes called "jelly melon," but that's much less badass). I made a shrub with it. This process extracted the flavors without having to worry about the weird texture of the fruit.

Shrub recipe:
8oz white vinegar
2oz apple balsamic vinegar
2oz @bullyhillvineyards red wine that I left sitting around too long (it's actually really good as a vinegar)
0.5 large horned melon contents
16oz Agave nectar

Add vinegars together and heat to almost boiling. Squeeze the contents of the melon into a jar. Pour vinegar mixture over melon. Seal and let sit for 1-4days. Add agave nectar and mix.

Drink recipe:
2oz Reposado tequila
2oz Horned Shrub
Juice of 1 lime

Add ingredients over ice. Shake. Strain into a rocks glass. Garnish with the husk of horned melon on fire!

Disclaimer: Fuego es peligroso üî•

Thousands of dollars spent on supplies. Hundreds of drinks mixed, served, and drunk. More than 1,000 Instagram followers and 350 posts. And somehow, my cocktail career had brought me to this: a chocolate milk tasting. ....what a life. Unfortunately, my palate isn't quite fully accustomed to this but I will try to do the best I can.

The Fresh Price was as basic as I was expecting. Very thin and the chocolate taste is weak. The drink has a much maltier taste reminding me of Ovaltine back in the States.

Matilde is also thin with a light mouth feel and a little dry (if you can use that word to describe chocolate milk!). The chocolate seems like an afterthought conceding flavor profile a starchy sugar taste like marshmallow.

Cocio classic is definitely the thickest and the sweetest with the chocolate flavor being pure and the most unadulterated.

Cocio Rich Dark Taste certainly lives up to it's name providing the same qualities as the classic recipe with a darker flavor profile indictive of cocoa and darker chocolate.

Now the question becomes: which one makes the best cocktail?? #tasting #chocolatemilk #chocolate #stomachache #cocktails #drinks #MixedDrinks #Mixology #HomeBartender #cheers #sk√•l #Alcohol #liquor #liqueur @cociouk

You know I'm getting back into the mixology groove when I have random jars sitting around making syrups and the like. This one here is a citrus cordial. I got the recipe from @selmasaur and I'm super excited to give it a try.

In her book "Spirit of the North", Selma writes:
1 C freshly-squeezed lemon juice
1 C freshly-squeezed orange juice
1 C superfine sugar

Mix well until sugar is completely dissolved, than add the peels of the oranges and lemons used for juicing. Let sit overnight at a minimum, with the peels of the oranges and lemons, but up to 2 days for the perfect yield. Strain before use.

So @barreloftiki is doing this event reminiscent of the use of secret ingredients in tiki drinks. I had to try it out. My secret ingredient is actually the spirit. It's a delicate combination of 3 different vodkas. One is made from wheat, one is made from sweet potatoes, one is made from apples. One adds spice, one adds body, one adds sweetness. It's a rather tricky mix to come by as I've only found one distillery (in NC) that makes the sweet potato and one distillery (in NY) which makes the apple, but then again, if a secret was easy, how much fun would that be?? I added some banana liqueur I had around and garnished with little plastic monkeys. Since this is supposed to be a barrel tiki drink, I call it 'Barrel of Monkeys'

2.5oz Secret Vodka Mix
0.5oz banana liqueur
0.5oz Cr√®me de Noyaux
1oz Falernum
2oz Pineapple juice
1dash black walnut bitters

Add ingredients together over ice. Stir. Strain. Garnish with a lemon wheel and plastic monkeys.

I love testing out mocktails and adding them to my repertoire. They're fun and a great way to have designated drivers feel like they're still participating. Like @all.equal.parts I too have a problem if they're too sugary, so this post of his really caught my attention.
***
 üçáüèòÔ∏èüå≥Long Way Home, a zero-proof cocktail to start the week. I'm not personally doing sober October, but I'm sure some of you are. So here is something to help you scratch that itch. I came up with this one almost two years ago for the @homebarawards. I'm still a sucker for a zero-proof drink that aren't syrupy sweet nonsense.
üå≥üèòÔ∏èüå≥
To be honest, that may be my biggest pet peeves in mixology: "mocktails" that are nothing but juice and syrup and make you think you are back in kindergarten slurping down an off-brand Sunny D. Creating a good mocktail doesn't have to be complicated. There are a lot of non-alcoholic spirits out there now that can be delicious when used properly. Even more, utilizing something other than tart and sweet ingredients can also help. In today's cocktail I used a lemon tonic from @fevertreemixers, which brings a bitter component. This drink is bright, refreshing, and full of lemon and blueberry deliciousness.
üèòÔ∏èüèòÔ∏èüèòÔ∏è
Recipe:
- 1 oz blueberry syrup
- 6 mint leaves
- 2 dashes orange blossom water
- 3/4 oz lemon sherbet
- 3 oz bitter lemon soda
ü•Ç
Add the mint, orange blossom water, and blueberry syrup to a tall glass. Gently muddle the mint. Add the lemon sherbet and about half the soda. Fill the glass 3/4 full with ice and swizzle. Add the rest of the soda and top with ice. Garnish with more mint.
ü•Çü•Çü•Ç

A friend of mine recently stumbled upon an article about this one. 'The Alaska' is simply gin and yellow chartreuse. Issue is: I only have green chartreuse. Apparently the difference is mainly just the addition of honey to temper the herbal notes, so I decided to make some makeshift yellow from my green. The choice of gin is incredibly important. This one comes from a small winery in Upstate New York. It's subtle and peppery making it a nice one to pair with the chartreuse. So, here's my take on 'The Alaska' (thanks for the inspiration, Dov)! *
1.5oz gin (#demaresthillwinery)
0.5oz green chartreuse
2bar spoons of honey syrup (1:1V)
2dashes of orange bitters

Stir gin, chartreuse, and honey over ice. Strain into a coup glass. Add bitters. Serve.
*

Do it once, it's novel; do it twice, it's tradition. Here is the second year of Joe's Easter Limoncello. Limoncello is a great spring drink. Its light citrus flavor and bright color are the perfect match for warming weather and brightening sun. Also it's a great thing to bring to Easter dinner with the family.

Preparation:
-Peel 8 lemons. Be careful to get minimal pith (the white part on the back)
-Put peels in a bottle
-Fill bottle with 100 proof vodka (I used @mr.bostonofficial )
-Let sit for forty days and forty nights.
-Flip upside down, for shaking purposes, once a day or so
-Assemble two or more friends
-Add alcohol mixture, simple syrup, and water until desired flavor and consistency is reached
-Cheers!

Old Forester Signature Bourbon deserves a place on your home bourbon bar. The value is a no-brainer at its price, and the flavors are complex and well developed. Interesting fact - this rich and complex spirit was the first bottled bourbon to be sold to the public. Spicy and robust, it is bottled at 100 Proof to maintain its distinct character and full flavor profile. On the nose, it is strong, sweet coffee laced with chocolate, creamy butterscotch and a hint of licorice. In taste, there are hints of ripe apple and other sweet fruit, bakery spice, and toasted oak, which lingers on the tongue. Old Forester is one of the base ingredients used in our Jungleland cocktail. üì∑: @ericmedsker

Here's my entry for the March @homebarawards challenge. The topic: The Big Screen. A movie inspired cocktail. There's no movie that deserves a drink more than 'Citizen Kane'. Called "the most influential movie ever made" and "the #1 movie of all time," nominated for 9 academy awards and winner of Best Original Screenplay (1942), this film has withstood the test of time and still tops lists by USA today and IGN. I couldn't help but use the imagery, inspiration, and innovation to drive my cocktail.
---
The movie:
'Citizen Kane' follows the journey of reporter Jerry Thompson (William Alland) as he tries to uncover the meaning of the final words of newspaper tycoon Charles Foster Kane (Orson Welles). Thompson follows Kane's troubled life from when his family became unexpectedly wealthy, to the building of his newspaper empire, through two marriages and subsequent divorces, to the raising of a castle, all concluding with his lonely final moments as he uttered his last word: "Rosebud." The film paints the portrait of a life corrupted by money, control, and an unsatisfied longing for something else.
---
The drink:
'Rosebud'
1 sugar cube
4-6 rose petals
1 bar spoon of rose syrup
2oz American whiskey 
Muddle sugar cube, rose petals, and rose syrup together. Add whiskey. Add ice and stir. Double strain into a glass over an ice ball (snow-globe) containing a rose.
---
The symbolism:
*The picture is grainy and black and white with dynamic lighting to mirror the film itself.
*The drink is a take-off of an Old Fashioned. The simplicity of the drink represents the simplicity of the life Charles Foster Kane longed for and had ripped away from him. His fortune, art, and prestige never made him content.
*The rose petals and syrup add the floral notes giving the drink its name: 'Rosebud'
*I chose American whiskey because, as the man himself said: "I AM, HAVE BEEN, AND WILL BE ONLY ONE THING - AN AMERICAN."
*The garnish is a rose encased in a "snow-globe." These are the memories Kane yearns so much to have to fill his cold and empty life.

#whiskey #rose #blackandwhite #CitizenKane #homebarawards #mixology #HomeBartender

I love this post from @thebitterfairy for three reasons: (A) it sounds delicious and I'm seriously going to try it... Blue cheese in a martini??? Awesome! (2) She is bold and unapologetic and that's wonderful! (III) I love the little sword. ***
I will not apologize. Everyone has an opinion on what makes a martini perfect, but my opinion is that the perfect martini is the one that you love best. So if you are the sort who is always going to wish you had one more olive no matter how many there are, who wants olives AND pickled onions, who actually wants to taste the vermouth, who also wants stinky cheese, and who wants ice because you want your damn martini to stay cold the entire time you're enjoying it... Well then, clearly you are me. üôÉ And I am here to stand up for the right to boldly have your druthers in a martini, in a world where everyone's a critic. ‚Å£
‚Å£
This martini has a secret weapon: blue cheese. My wild, sweet, hilarious friend @cocktailsmandurah, who is somewhat famous (notorious?) for her ability to make the most intensely delicious syrups and infusions imaginable, persuaded me to make a blue cheese fat-washed gin (see her page for recipe), and oh my holy word, it is so fracking delicious that it's hard to stop thinking about even for a day. If you like salty, funky, cheesy things, this could become your new obsession. It makes the ultimate savory gin martini.‚Å£
‚Å£
This cocktail is packed with blue cheese-stuffed olives, anchovy-stuffed olives, and chile-spiced pickled onions. Stinky cheese, salty fishes, and spicy/vinegar-y onions, and gin. The very dream. Which is why I made a not-tiny one. I mean, who wants the dream martini that's gone in the blink of an eye? A taste of honey is worse than none at all.‚Å£
‚Å£
Do you have a no-apologies beloved cocktail?‚Å£
‚Å£
Blue Cheese Martini Heaven‚Å£
‚Å£
1 1/2 oz blue cheese-washed gin*‚Å£
1 1/2 oz gin (I prefer a strong juniper bomb here because I wanted ice)‚Å£
1 oz dry vermouth‚Å£
many, many olives and pickled onions‚Å£

When your 9yro kid is a picky eater, you make peanut butter and jelly for lunch. When you are a picky drinker, have my 'PB&J Martini' for happy hour! {Please note: @chemistry.cocktails does not approve of feeding 9 year old children martinis for lunch}

Bottom:
Your favorite jelly flavored liqueur (I chose black raspberry schnapps)

Top:
1.5oz cream
1.5oz vodka
2T peanut butter
1T sugar

Add all top ingredients in a shaker and shake. ....like really shake. ...like forget egg white level shaking, you need to shake this baby until your arm falls off and then have your friend help. Add ice and shake again (too much shaking WITH ice will dilute the drink). Pour your jelly layer into your glass, layer on your peanut butter layer.

Celebrating my man @welcometomybar and his 10,000 followers (that's a lot of zeros!) My contribution to #fedes10ktikiparty is this bad boy. As I've said before, I don't have the appropriate tiki mug for this beverage, but I'm hoping my garnish game will make up for that. This is a boozy drink, so I'm calling it "The Tipsy Tiki"
-
0.5oz coconut rum
0.5oz white rum
1.0oz spiced rum
1.0oz gold rum
1.5oz pineapple juice
1.5oz orange juice
0.5oz grenadine
0.5oz Turbinado simple syrup
0.5oz orgeat syrup
Add ingredients together and shake with ice. Take a slice of pinapple and orange. Sprinkle fruit with sugar in the raw. Put fruit onto frying pan and sear until sugar is caramelized (it looks burnt, but it's delicious). Pour mix into glass. Set orange slice on top. Put straw through orange slice. Put pineapple and rum soaked cherry on the side of the glass (you're gonna be a rum soaked cherry if you have too many of these). Finish with a tiny umbrella.

The events of #AverageAugust are supposed to venerate the "average" home bar, but for my mid-week posts, I want to share some tips and tricks that could help an "average" bar become a little more.

I've noticed a lot of people have various flavors of rum and vodka. With a few exceptions, I shy away from this preferring, instead, to use schnapps or a similar liqueur. One doesn't need cinnamon vodka when one has regular vodka and cinnamon schnapps. Just mix the two together. Is it the same? Not exactly, but it stands as a decent substitute. The sugar in the schnapps also helps make the drink more approachable, and you can mediate exactly how much flavor you want based on how much schnapps you add. The best part is, these bottles tend to be cheap ($6-$15 a bottle) and will last for a while. So, in the future, instead of picking up raspberry rum, try some white rum and raspberry schnapps...you might just find your inner mixologist!

#AverageAugust tip number 2: buy cans! Got a big party coming up? You might be tempted to buy 2L big bottles of mixers, but soda goes flat and juice goes moldy. In cans, every drink you make has the same fresh mixer taste. If you don't finish it all during your party, you've got some for next time. And it will (probably) be just as good as when you first bought it. (Just remember to recycle)

Inspired by the 21st amendment and a bad pun, this is my "Re-peel Day Sazerac"

Preparation:
Soak orange peel in cognac overnight.

Recipe:
2oz orange infused cognac
0.5oz @grandmarnierusa 
1cube sugar
2dashes orange bitters
2dashes absinthe

Method:
Rinse glass with 1dash absinthe. Add ice water and set aside. Soak sugar cube in 2dashes orange bitters and 1dash absinthe. Muddle. Add ice. Add cognac and Grand Marnier. Stir. Discard ice water from glass. Strain cocktail into glass over ice. Garnish with the orange peel that was used to flavor the cognac (repeal... re-peel.... Alright, stay with me for this one, because things are about to get weird! ....the other night I had a craving for a Ramos Gin Fizz. ... problem was: I didn't have any cream and hardly any gin. So I decided to substitute the cream with milk and cream of coconut (not coconut cream, that would have made Some sense) and the gin with rum (told you it got weird). ...it turned out amazing!! ...it's nothing like a Ramos Gin Fizz, but whatever it is, it's delicious!! I give you, 'The Makeshift Gin Fizz'

0.5oz lime juice
0.5oz lemon juice
1.0oz simple syrup
1.0oz milk (I used skim)
1.0oz Cream of coconut
1.0oz gin
2.0oz rum
5drops orange blossom water
1 egg white

Add ingredients (without the egg white) to a shaker with ice. Shake (hard!). Strain ice out. Add egg white. Shake again (harder!). Pour into glass. Top with club soda and garnish with a lime wheel.

So, I went to my copy of "Smuggler's Cove" and found this great recipe for 'The Undead Gentleman'. ***
***
0.5oz lime juice
0.5oz grapefruit juice
0.5oz cinnamon syrup
0.5oz falernum
1oz black blended overproof rum
1.5oz blended aged rum
1dash Angostura bitters
1dash Absinthe

Rinse a chilled cocktail coupe with absinthe. Add the remaining ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice, shake, and double strain into the coupe. Lime twist for garnish.

This concoction is a black pepper strawberry shrub. I got the recipe from @foodrepublic . It has a really nice balance and I've found a ton of fun uses. I actually made this batch back when strawberries were in season and froze it so I could enjoy some summer flavors this winter.

3/4 cup chopped ripe strawberries
3 tablespoons sugar
1 teaspoon coarsely ground black pepper
1 cup white balsamic vinegar

Add everything except vinegar and let macerate for 30 min. Add vinegar and let sit in the fridge for 2 days. Strain and enjoy.

This week's cocktail is my submission for the contest being held by @liquordotcom for the new "Star Wars" movie. I'm so excited!!!!!!!! Reminscent of the blood crimson blades wielded by the sith, I fashioned my own lightsaber. As Darth Maul would say, "Let it be nothing more than what it is; an instrument of [drinking], and nameless."
-
Hilt
0.5oz simple syrup
Sprinkle of silver pearl dust

Blade
3oz cranberry juice
1oz Aperol
1oz Campari
1oz Vodka

Construction
Add the simple syrup and pearl dust to the bottom of the glass and stir. Add ingredients for the blade to a mixing glass with ice. Shake. Painfully slowly layer. Take this time to meditate and channel the force. Frivolous things like garnish are not necessary.
-

An original twist on a classic favorite. Shout out to @mdosterling for the orange blossom water that makes this 'Ramos Joe Fizz'

2pts gin
1pt orange juice

3drops orange blossom water
1 egg white

Here's a cocktail take on a classic snack. The 'chocolate-dipped frozen banana'

Chocolate layer.
In a blender add...
1/4 of your banana
3/4oz Cr√®me de cocoa
3/4oz cream
1/2 scoop ice cream
Squirt of chocolate Syrup
Blend and pour into the bottom of your glass.

Banana layer.
In a blender add...
1.5oz 99 bananaa
1.5oz milk

Blend and layer on top of the chocolate layer.

Welcome back to another exciting installment of #AverageAugust . This drink comes inspired by @bbovenz . It's a little like if a martini and a Ramos Gin Fiz had a baby. I was given... *Whiskey (rye, Scotch, Irish)
*Spiced Rum
*Gin
*Irish cream
*Vermouth
*Angostura bitters
*Orange juice
*Cola

From that, I assembled the 'Bovenz-tini'
2oz gin
0.5oz sweet vermouth
1oz orange juice
Fill with lemon seltzer

Stir gin, vermouth, and OJ together, with ice, in a mixing glass. Strain into a martini glass. Top with seltzer. Garnish with lemon wedge.

1 cup water
1 cup sugar
1/4 vanilla bean

So, we're getting down to the end of #AverageAugust, and I've decided to make a pitch for 2 ingredient cocktails. They're simple, delicious, and totally easy to make in a home bar. Just because the name IS the recipe, doesn't mean it's any less of a stand-up drink. A working knowledge of these simple drinks can also fool your friends into thinking you're a real bartender! Pictured here, (left to right, back to front) are a 'Grayhound' (grapefruit juice and vodka), 'Rum & Coke (dark rum and cola), 'Gin & Tonic' (gin and tonic), and a '7&7' (whiskey and lemon-lime soda). Ratios are whatever the drinker likes best!
